items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 05:30 on 29/11/22 may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 135 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the nextÂ few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 29/11/22, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the Upper River Wey, especially in the Passfield Mill areas. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today. No further rainfall is forecast. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 29/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message: River levels remain high and steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby, the Mountsorrel to Sileby road, the access road to Sileby Mill, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes. No further rainfall is forecast however the river is not expected to drop below the flood risk threshold until tomorrow, 29/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 08:00 tomorrow, 29/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the past few days.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   
  River levels are beginning to fall, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Tuesday, 29/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. The weather forecast is dry. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if necessary.

River levels are high but falling at the Willington and Shardlow river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high today and into tomorrow morning, 29/11/2022. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 on 29/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Torksey and Gainsborough river gauges as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels.  Flooding continues.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 29/11/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further rainfall is forecast for the next couple of days.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message: The River Uck is slowly falling, following Sunday's rain. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads and gardens, will reduce by Monday afternoon. Showers Monday morning are unlikely to cause significant response in river levels and high pressure with dry days are forecast for the rest of the week. The River Uck should return nearer to normal by Tuesday. However, the river will remain sensitive to future rainfall, should wet weather return next week or through December. We will open our flood gate in Uckfield town centre supermarket car park Monday morning. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases.

items.message:
River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall but are starting to fall. Risk of flooding remains overnight Monday, 28/11/2022 into Tuesday. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads around Forest Row, Hartfield and Penshurst and around Balls Green and Ashurst.   
The weather for the next few days is largely settled with potential for the odd shower. We expect river levels to remain high until 08:00am on 29/11/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the River Medway. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 29/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ifield Brook, River Mole, Gatwick Stream, Burstow Stream

items.message: River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. The next 48 hours will generally remain dry. Further periods of heavy rainfall are expected on Friday 2 December. We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this flood alert if required.

The River Adur is high but slowly falling, following Sunday's rain. Flooding will continue to affect gardens and properties near Mock Bridge. Water will be extensive through fields and affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. Showers Monday morning (28/11/2022) are unlikely to cause significant rise in river levels but might delay the river's fall by a few hours Monday afternoon. From Monday afternoon (28/11/2022) high pressure is forecast to bring predominantly dry days until at least the weekend. River levels will continue to fall all week. Flood impacts will reduce by Tuesday (29/11/2022), but the River Adur is unlikely to return nearer to normal until Wednesday (30/11/2022). Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge may be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 29/11/2022.

The water level in the Eastern Yar remains higher than normal. In the last 24 hours, only 5mm of rain has been recorded at Wroxall. At Alverstone, the river is falling at a rate of 2cm per hour. At Sandown, the river level is currently peaking and is expected to begin falling this afternoon (28/11/2022). Minor flood impacts affecting roads (including Golf Links Road, and Moreton Common Road), cycle tracks, footpaths and gardens will continue throughout the Yar Valley today (28/11/2022). At Sandown, ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. From Tuesday (29/11/2022), a period of high pressure builds and the weather is expected to remain dry for the next 4 days. This will give the river a chance to recover but levels are unlikely to return to normal until later this week. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. This message will be removed by 14:00 on Tuesday 29/11/2022.

The River Ouse is high, but slowly falling, following Sunday's rain. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens all along the upper Ouse and affect rural roads such as at Sloop Lane, Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge and Barcombe Mills Road. The Anchor Inn and Anchor Lane will also be affected by flood water. Showers Monday morning (28/11/2022) are unlikely to cause significant response in river levels and the River Ouse should continue to slowly fall. From Monday afternoon (28/11/2022) high pressure is forecast to bring predominantly dry days until at least the weekend. The River Ouse will slowly fall in all communities all week. Flood impacts should reduce Tuesday (29/11/2022), but river levels could remain higher than normal until midweek in Barcombe. Please keep flood protection products in place in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 on 29/11/2022.

The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers through Hellingly, and the Cuckmere River through Alfriston are high but slowly falling, following Sunday's rain. Flood impacts will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens on Mill Lane, Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road Hellingly. As well as North Street, Litlington Road, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Showers Monday morning are unlikely to cause significant response in river levels. From Monday afternoon high pressure is forecast to bring predominantly dry days until at least the weekend. The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers will slowly fall in all communities all week. Flood impacts should reduce Tuesday, but river levels could remain higher than normal until midweek, possibly a little later in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 29/11/2022.

items.message:
River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall but are starting to fall. Risk of flooding remains overnight Monday, 28/11/2022 into Tuesday. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads particularly around Crowhurst Bridge, Shrub Lane and Robertsbridge.
The weather for the next few days is largely settled with potential for the odd shower. We expect river levels to remain high until 08:00am on 29/11/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the River Rother. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 29/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall combined with high tides. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue Monday evening, 28/11/2022 overnight into Tuesday. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Medway particularly footpaths and riverside areas in the Maidstone area and along the River Medway particularly around Aylesford.  
The weather for the next few days is largely settled with potential for the odd shower. We expect river levels to remain high until 08:00am on 29/11/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the River Medway. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 29/11/2022, or as the situation changes

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding, although standing water and debris may remain. Further localised heavy rainfall is forecast for today. Remain aware of your local situation.

We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.

The Western Rother is high and slowly rising at Fittleworth, following Sunday's rain. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and riverside properties at Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth. Only minimal flood impacts are currently expected in Liss, Sheet, Iping and Midhurst, where the Western Rother has already fallen nearer to normal. Showers Monday morning are unlikely to cause a significant rise in river levels. From Monday afternoon high pressure is forecast to bring predominantly dry days until at least the weekend. The Western Rother should begin to fall in Fittleworth by 14:00 Monday 28/11/2022. Minor flood impacts will remain in Fittleworth until midweek, and the river will not return nearer to normal until the weekend. In all other communities, the Western Rother should return nearer to normal by midweek. Please keep flood protection products in place at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 29/11/2022.

River levels in Crowhurst are still high following Sunday's rain, but are now falling. In Bulverhythe, water levels will rise by about 30cm over each high tide, but at low tide, the river will fall in Bulverhythe too. Flooding will continue to affect gardens of riverside properties in Crowhurst, as well as fields, rural roads, Crowhurst Recreation Ground, and Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Showers Monday morning are unlikely to cause significant response in river levels. From Monday afternoon high pressure is forecast to bring predominantly dry days until at least the weekend. The rivers of the Combe Haven will slowly fall in all communities all week. Flood impacts should reduce in Crowhurst by Tuesday. However, in Bulverhythe, river levels could remain higher than normal until the end of the week, with flood water continuing to affect Bexhill Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Please take care if walking near flood water, it can be deep and contain hidden dangers. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 29/11/2022.

Tide levels on early Tuesday morning at 03:00 (29/11/2022) are forecast to be lower than those experienced Monday afternoon at Climping. Only minimal flood impacts are expected. There may still be some minor pooling at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane, but expect this to reduce over the next few days.  Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 03:00 Tuesday morning (29/11/2022) will be 5.66 metres Chart Datum (2.61 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Tides will gradually reduce as the week continues. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. In order to reduce flood risk to property, our operations staff have moved shingle to try and improve the beach crest. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

The River Arun is high and slowly rising between Pallingham Quay and Pulborough, following Sunday's rain. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and isolated mill properties. River levels at Pallingham Lock should begin to fall Monday afternoon. Showers Monday morning are unlikely to cause significant response in river levels. From Monday afternoon, high pressure is forecast to bring predominantly dry days until at least the weekend. The River Arun will slowly fall, in all communities, all week. Flood impacts should reduce in Horsham and Broadbridge Heath by Tuesday. However, nearer Pulborough, river levels could remain higher than normal until next week. Please keep flood protection products installed in Wanford as a precaution, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 11:00 29/11/2022.

The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes are high, but currently falling, following an extremely wet November. Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, parts of the car park at Tesco and Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Only minor flood impacts are expected in Barnham. Showers Monday morning might cause a brief and small river rise in Barnham, but from Monday afternoon high pressure is forecast to bring predominantly dry days until at least the weekend. The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes should slowly fall during the week, however, through Shripney and Bersted minor flood impacts will continue. It will likely take a fortnight of dry weather for river levels to return nearer to normal. River levels will remain sensitive to future rainfall. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We continue to routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 on 29/11/2022.

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the last 2 days.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today.  We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 29/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.49 m and is currently falling by 40 mm an hour. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.30 m and very slowly rising. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m and the road from Muchelney to Long load above 7.86 m. Pumping will take place at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station when river levels allow.
A largely dry day is forecast for today, Monday 28/11/22 although there is possibility of some short showers. Dry weather is then set to continue through the week. This flood alert remains in force due to water on the moors in the area and the risk of road flooding.  
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Tuesday, 29/11/2022, or as the situation changes. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

The weather for the next few days is largely settled with potential for the odd shower. We expect river levels to remain high until 08:00am on 29/11/2022.

River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.  Please refer to the local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on Tuesday, 29/11/22, or as the situation changes.

Water levels in the River Blackwater at Ower remain high but are falling. Only a small amount of rain (up to 9 mm) is forecast over the next 24 hours. This may cause a minor increase in water level, but the forecast does not suggest any imminent flood risk. From Tuesday (29/11/2022), a period of high pressure builds and the weather is expected to remain dry for the next 4 days. This will give the river a chance to recover. We expect water levels to return to normal tomorrow, any minor flood impacts should reduce significantly by this time. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information.

items.message:
River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall. Risk of flooding remains overnight Monday, 28/11/2022 into Tuesday. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the River Beult, particularly around Smarden and Bethersden.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.43 m and has just started to slowly rise. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.98 m and is very slowly rising. Pumping will take place at Currymoor when the river levels allow. 
A largely dry day is forecast for today, Monday 28/11/22 although there is the possibility of some short showers. Dry weather is then set to continue through the week. This flood alert remains in force due to water on the moors but with the dry weather, the situation will improve.  
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Tuesday, 29/11/2022, or as the situation changes. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff will be checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

This Flood Alert has been removed.Â  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.Â  
We continue to monitor the situation.Â

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the middle to lower part of the River Cherwell as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week. Further flooding of roads and farmland is not expected, however water will remain out of banks especially in the areas around Thrupp. There is very little rain forecast for today (Monday), there maybe a few scattered showers. We expect river levels to remain high for the next couple of days.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Tuesday, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: The River Nene has being falling steadily today Monday 28th November. North Bank Road will be reopened once the Highways Authority have been able to inspect the road surface and carry out any necessary works to ensure the road is passable. There may be standing water in low lying areas and fields for several days.

There is very little rain forecast for today (Monday), there maybe a few scattered showers. 
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
This message will be updated on Tuesday, or as the situation changes.

Tide levels on early Tuesday morning at 03:00 (29/11/2022) are forecast to be lower than those experienced Monday afternoon at Climping. Only minimal flood impacts are expected. There may still be some minor pooling at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane, but expect this to reduce over the next few days.  Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 03:00 Tuesday morning (29/11/2022) will be 5.66 metres Chart Datum (2.61 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Tides will gradually reduce as the week continues. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. In order to reduce flood risk to property, our operations staff have moved shingle to try and improve the beach crest. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

River levels are high but steady at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge.   
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 10am on 29/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Frome from Maiden Newton to Dorchester

items.message: River levels remain high at the Briantspuddle river gauge on the River Piddle as a result of the heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  River levels are starting to fall, but still pose a flood risk between Alton Pancras and Wareham.  We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are out checking defences.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.  Please refer to the local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on Tuesday, 29/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the River Leach as a result of a period of sustained rainfall over the past few weeks. Further flooding of roads and farmland is not expected, however water will remain out of banks especially in the areas around Lechlade.   
There is very little rain forecast for today (Monday), there maybe a few scattered showers. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Tuesday, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have been high on the River Thames as a result of a period of sustained rainfall over the past few weeks. Therefore, flooding of low laying land is expected to continue, specifically between Sandford Lock and Abingdon Lock.   
There is very little rain forecast for today (Monday), there maybe a few scattered showers. River levels are not expected to get much higher than they currently are but are expected to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been operating weirs to reduce flood risk. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on Tuesday, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Frome from East Stoke to Wareham
Lower Frome from Dorchester to East Stoke

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days from today, 28/11/2022.  
We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days from today, 28/11/2022.  
We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and remain aware of your local situation.

items.description: Tidal River Stour area from Fordwich to Stonar Cut
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 3:30am and 5:30am tomorrow, 29/11/2022 in areas around Grove Ferry and Plucks Gutter.
No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. We expect river levels at Grove Ferry to reach an approximate level of 2.36 metres above Ordnance Datum on the high tide at 4:30am, Tuesday 29/11/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near the River Stour, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 29/11/2022, or as the situation changes.
